sn21.2:2.1: “Just now, reverends, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:
sn21.2:2.2: ‘Is there anything in the world whose changing and perishing would give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in me?’
sn21.2:2.4: ‘There is nothing in the world whose changing and perishing would give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in me.’”
sn21.2:3.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to him,
sn21.2:3.2: “Even if the Teacher were to decay and perish? Wouldn’t that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in you?”
sn21.2:3.3: “Even if the Teacher were to decay and perish, that wouldn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in me. Still, I would think:
sn21.2:3.4: ‘Alas, the illustrious Teacher, so mighty and powerful, has vanished!
sn21.2:3.5: If the Buddha was to remain for a long time, that would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.’”
sn21.2:3.6: “That must be because Venerable Sāriputta has long ago totally eradicated ego, possessiveness, and the underlying tendency to conceit.
sn21.2:3.7: So even if the Teacher were to decay and perish, it wouldn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in him.”
